integration-trap-story.text: The Task Arrives. Picture this: your manager says integrate with Stripe for payments. Seems straightforward, right? The docs have examples. Stack Overflow has answers. What could go wrong?
The Junior Approach. The junior reads the docs, copies the example code, tests it locally — it works! Ship it. Pull request merged. Feature deployed. Everyone's happy... for now.

The 3am Wake-Up Call. Two weeks later, 3am. Your phone explodes. Payments are failing. Stripe is rate-limiting you because a marketing campaign drove 10x traffic. No retry logic. No alerts. Just angry customers.

The Senior Approach. Seniors don't just think about the happy path. They ask: What if the API is slow? What if it fails? What if we hit rate limits? What if it's completely down? Each question becomes a layer of protection.
The Mindset Shift. The difference between junior and senior isn't years of experience — it's asking what could go wrong before it does. Juniors hope APIs work. Seniors plan for when they don't.

checklist-story.text: Authentication & Security. First, security. API keys belong in a vault, not your code. Different keys for dev, staging, and production. And document how to rotate them — because you will need to rotate them eventually.

Error Handling. Next, errors. Implement retry with exponential backoff — wait longer between each attempt. Add a circuit breaker to stop cascading failures. Plan graceful degradation. And always set timeouts — never wait forever.

Rate Limiting. Know their rate limits — actually read the docs. Implement client-side throttling so you never hit those limits. Add a queue for handling traffic bursts. Don't let a marketing email take down your payments.
Monitoring. Track latency — not just average, but p50, p95, p99. Alert on error rate spikes. Correlate with business metrics. You want to know about problems before your customers tell you.

Testing. Finally, testing. Use mocks for unit tests — don't hit real APIs. Use sandbox environments for integration tests. And critically: test failure scenarios. What happens when the API returns 500? Simulate it.

resilience-story.text: Why Resilience Matters. In distributed systems, failure isn't a possibility — it's a certainty. Networks drop packets. Services crash. APIs hit limits. Resilience isn't about preventing failures; it's about surviving them gracefully.

Retry with Exponential Backoff. When a call fails, don't immediately retry — you'll make things worse. Wait one second, then two, then four. This exponential backoff gives overloaded systems time to recover. Set a max attempts limit so you don't retry forever.

Circuit Breaker: Closed State. A circuit breaker starts closed — requests flow through normally. It tracks failures. If everything works, great. But if failures start piling up, it's watching, counting, ready to act.

Circuit Breaker: Open State. When failures exceed a threshold, the circuit opens. Now it fails fast — requests don't even try to reach the broken service. This protects your system from cascading failures and gives the external service time to recover.

Recovery: Half-Open State. After a timeout, the circuit enters half-open state. It allows a few test requests through. If they succeed, the circuit closes — back to normal. If they fail, it opens again. This automatic recovery means you don't need manual intervention at 3am.
